comment:
The compiler depends on the System module to work properly and the System
## module depends on the compiler. Most of the routines listed here use
## special compiler magic.
## Each module implicitly imports the System module; it must not be listed
## explicitly. Because of this there cannot be a user-defined module named
## ``system``.
##
## Exception hierarchy
## ===================
##
## For visual convenience here is the exception inheritance hierarchy
## represented as a tree:
##
## .. include:: ../doc/exception_hierarchy_fragment.txt
##
## Module system
## =============
##

name: float64
description: 64 bit floating point type

name: bool
description: built-in boolean type

name: pointer
description: built-in pointer type, use the addr operator to get a pointer to a variable

name: off
description: alias for false

name: SomeNumber
description: type class matching all number types

name: defined
description:
Special compile-time procedure that checks whether x is defined. x is an external symbol introduced through the compiler's -d:x switch to enable build time conditionals:
when not defined(release):
  # Do here programmer friendly expensive sanity checks.
# Put here the normal code

name: declared
description:
Special compile-time procedure that checks whether x is declared. x has to be an identifier or a qualified identifier. This can be used to check whether a library provides a certain feature or not:
when not defined(strutils.toUpper):
  # provide our own toUpper proc here, because strutils is
  # missing it.

name: definedInScope
description: Deprecated since version 0.9.6: Use declaredInScope instead.
code:
proc definedInScope*(x: expr): bool {.magic: "DefinedInScope", noSideEffect, 
                                      deprecated.}

name: declaredInScope
description: Special compile-time procedure that checks whether <cite>x</cite> is declared in the current scope. <cite>x</cite> has to be an identifier.

name: `not`
description: Boolean not; returns true iff x == false.

name: `and`
description: Boolean and; returns true iff x == y == true. Evaluation is lazy: if x is false, y will not even be evaluated.

name: `or`
description: Boolean or; returns true iff not (not x and not y). Evaluation is lazy: if x is true, y will not even be evaluated.

name: `xor`
description: Boolean exclusive or; returns true iff x != y.

name: new
description: creates a new object of type T and returns a safe (traced) reference to it in a.
code: proc new*[T](a: var ref T) {.magic: "New", noSideEffect.}

name: new
description: creates a new object of type T and returns a safe (traced) reference to it as result value

name: unsafeNew
description: creates a new object of type T and returns a safe (traced) reference to it in a. This is unsafe as it allocates an object of the passed size. This should only be used for optimization purposes when you know what you're doing!
code: proc unsafeNew*[T](a: var ref T; size: int) {.magic: "New", noSideEffect.}

name: internalNew
description: leaked implementation detail. Do not use.
code: proc internalNew*[T](a: var ref T) {.magic: "New", noSideEffect.}

name: new
description: creates a new object of type T and returns a safe (traced) reference to it in a. When the garbage collector frees the object, finalizer is called. The finalizer may not keep a reference to the object pointed to by x. The finalizer cannot prevent the GC from freeing the object. Note: The finalizer refers to the type T, not to the object! This means that for each object of type T the finalizer will be called!
code:
proc new*[T](a: var ref T; finalizer: proc (x: ref T) {.nimcall.}) {.
    magic: "NewFinalize", noSideEffect.}

name: reset
description: resets an object obj to its initial (binary zero) value. This needs to be called before any possible object branch transition.

name: high
description: returns the highest possible index of an array, a sequence, a string or the highest possible value of an ordinal value x. As a special semantic rule, x may also be a type identifier. high(int) is Nim's way of writing INT_MAX or MAX_INT.

name: low
description: returns the lowest possible index of an array, a sequence, a string or the lowest possible value of an ordinal value <cite>x</cite>. As a special semantic rule, <cite>x</cite> may also be a type identifier.

name: set
description: Generic type to construct bit sets.

name: Slice
description: builtin slice type
code:
Slice* {.final, pure.}[T] = object 
  a*, b*: T                   ## the bounds

description: slice operator that constructs an interval [a, b], both a and b are inclusive. Slices can also be used in the set constructor and in ordinal case statements, but then they are special-cased by the compiler.
slice operator that constructs an interval [default(T), b]

code: proc `==`*[TEnum: enum](x, y: TEnum): bool {.magic: "EqEnum", noSideEffect.}
proc `==`*[T](x, y: ref T): bool {.magic: "EqRef", noSideEffect.}
proc `==`*[T](x, y: ptr T): bool {.magic: "EqRef", noSideEffect.}
proc `==`*[T: proc](x, y: T): bool {.magic: "EqProc", noSideEffect.}

name: `<=`
code: proc `<=`*[TEnum: enum](x, y: TEnum): bool {.magic: "LeEnum", noSideEffect.}

name: `<=`
code: proc `<=`*[T](x, y: ref T): bool {.magic: "LePtr", noSideEffect.}

name: `<`
code: proc `<`*[TEnum: enum](x, y: TEnum): bool {.magic: "LtEnum", noSideEffect.}

name: `<`
code: proc `<`*[T](x, y: ref T): bool {.magic: "LtPtr", noSideEffect.}

name: `<`
code: proc `<`*[T](x, y: ptr T): bool {.magic: "LtPtr", noSideEffect.}

description: unequals operator. This is a shorthand for not (x == y).

name: `>=`
description: "is greater or equals" operator. This is the same as y <= x.

name: `>`
description: "is greater" operator. This is the same as y < x.

name: appType
description: a string that describes the application type. Possible values: "console", "gui", "lib".

name: NoFakeVars
description:
true if the backend doesn't support 
"fake variables" like 'var EBADF {.importc.}: cint'.

name: sizeof
description: returns the size of x in bytes. Since this is a low-level proc, its usage is discouraged - using new for the most cases suffices that one never needs to know x's size. As a special semantic rule, x may also be a type identifier (sizeof(int) is valid).

name: `<`
description:
unary < that can be used for nice looking excluding ranges:
for i in 0 .. <10: echo i

Semantically this is the same as pred.

name: succ
description: returns the y-th successor of the value x. T has to be an ordinal type. If such a value does not exist, EOutOfRange is raised or a compile time error occurs.
code: proc succ*[T](x: Ordinal[T]; y = 1): T {.magic: "Succ", noSideEffect.}

name: pred
description: returns the y-th predecessor of the value x. T has to be an ordinal type. If such a value does not exist, EOutOfRange is raised or a compile time error occurs.
code: proc pred*[T](x: Ordinal[T]; y = 1): T {.magic: "Pred", noSideEffect.}

name: inc
description: increments the ordinal x by y. If such a value does not exist, EOutOfRange is raised or a compile time error occurs. This is a short notation for: x = succ(x, y).
code:
proc inc*[T: Ordinal | uint | uint64](x: var T; y = 1) {.magic: "Inc", 
    noSideEffect.}

name: dec
description: decrements the ordinal x by y. If such a value does not exist, EOutOfRange is raised or a compile time error occurs. This is a short notation for: x = pred(x, y).
code:
proc dec*[T: Ordinal | uint | uint64](x: var T; y = 1) {.magic: "Dec", 
    noSideEffect.}

name: newSeq
description:
creates a new sequence of type seq[T] with length len. This is equivalent to s = @[]; setlen(s, len), but more efficient since no reallocation is needed.

Note that the sequence will be filled with zeroed entries, which can be a problem for sequences containing strings since their value will be nil. After the creation of the sequence you should assign entries to the sequence instead of adding them. Example:

var inputStrings : seq[string]
newSeq(inputStrings, 3)
inputStrings[0] = "The fourth"
inputStrings[1] = "assignment"
inputStrings[2] = "would crash"
#inputStrings[3] = "out of bounds"
code: proc newSeq*[T](s: var seq[T]; len: int) {.magic: "NewSeq", noSideEffect.}

name: newSeq
description:
creates a new sequence of type seq[T] with length len.

Note that the sequence will be filled with zeroed entries, which can be a problem for sequences containing strings since their value will be nil. After the creation of the sequence you should assign entries to the sequence instead of adding them. Example:

var inputStrings = newSeq[string](3)
inputStrings[0] = "The fourth"
inputStrings[1] = "assignment"
inputStrings[2] = "would crash"
#inputStrings[3] = "out of bounds"

name: len
code:
proc len*[TOpenArray: openArray | varargs](x: TOpenArray): int {.
    magic: "LengthOpenArray", noSideEffect.}

name: len
code: proc len*[I, T](x: array[I, T]): int {.magic: "LengthArray", noSideEffect.}

name: len
description: returns the length of an array, an openarray, a sequence or a string. This is rougly the same as high(T)-low(T)+1, but its resulting type is always an int.

name: incl
description: includes element y to the set x. This is the same as x = x + {y}, but it might be more efficient.
code: proc incl*[T](x: var set[T]; y: T) {.magic: "Incl", noSideEffect.}

name: incl
description: includes the set of flags to the set x.
code: template incl*[T](s: var set[T]; flags: set[T])

name: excl
description: excludes element y to the set x. This is the same as x = x - {y}, but it might be more efficient.
code: proc excl*[T](x: var set[T]; y: T) {.magic: "Excl", noSideEffect.}

name: excl
description: excludes the set of flags to x.
code: template excl*[T](s: var set[T]; flags: set[T])

name: card
description: returns the cardinality of the set x, i.e. the number of elements in the set.

name: ord
description: returns the internal int value of an ordinal value x.

name: chr
description: converts an int in the range 0..255 to a character.

name: ze
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int. This treats x as unsigned.

name: ze
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int. This treats x as unsigned.

name: ze64
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int64. This treats x as unsigned.

name: ze64
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int64. This treats x as unsigned.

name: ze64
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int64. This treats x as unsigned.

name: ze64
description: zero extends a smaller integer type to int64. This treats x as unsigned. Does nothing if the size of an int is the same as int64. (This is the case on 64 bit processors.)

name: toU8
description: treats <cite>x</cite> as unsigned and converts it to a byte by taking the last 8 bits from <cite>x</cite>.

name: toU16
description: treats x as unsigned and converts it to an int16 by taking the last 16 bits from x.

name: toU32
description: treats x as unsigned and converts it to an int32 by taking the last 32 bits from x.
Unary <cite>+</cite> operator for an integer. Has no effect.
Unary <cite>-</cite> operator for an integer. Negates <cite>x</cite>.

name: `not`
description: computes the <cite>bitwise complement</cite> of the integer <cite>x</cite>.
Binary <cite>+</cite> operator for an integer.
Binary <cite>-</cite> operator for an integer.
Binary <cite>*</cite> operator for an integer.

name: `div`
description:
computes the integer division. This is roughly the same as floor(x/y). .. code-block:: Nim

1 div 2 == 0 2 div 2 == 1 3 div 2 == 1

name: `mod`
description: computes the integer modulo operation. This is the same as x - (x div y) * y.

name: `shr`
description:
computes the shift right operation of x and y. .. code-block:: Nim

0b0001_0000'i8 shr 2 == 0b0100_0000'i8 0b1000_0000'i8 shr 2 == 0b0000_0000'i8 0b0000_0001'i8 shr 9 == 0b0000_0000'i8

name: `shl`
description: computes the <cite>shift left</cite> operation of <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>.

name: `and`
description: computes the <cite>bitwise and</cite> of numbers <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>.

name: `or`
description: computes the <cite>bitwise or</cite> of numbers <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>.

name: `xor`
description: computes the <cite>bitwise xor</cite> of numbers <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>.
Compares two integers for equality.

name: `<=`
description: Returns true iff <cite>x</cite> is less than or equal to <cite>y</cite>.

name: `<`
description: Returns true iff <cite>x</cite> is less than <cite>y</cite>.
treats <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite> as unsigned and adds them. The result is truncated to fit into the result. This implements modulo arithmetic. No overflow errors are possible.
treats <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite> as unsigned and subtracts them. The result is truncated to fit into the result. This implements modulo arithmetic. No overflow errors are possible.
treats <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite> as unsigned and multiplies them. The result is truncated to fit into the result. This implements modulo arithmetic. No overflow errors are possible.
treats <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite> as unsigned and divides them. The result is truncated to fit into the result. This implements modulo arithmetic. No overflow errors are possible.

treats <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite> as unsigned and compute the modulo of <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>. The result is truncated to fit into the result. This implements modulo arithmetic. No overflow errors are possible.

name: `<=%`
description: treats x and y as unsigned and compares them. Returns true iff unsigned(x) <= unsigned(y).

name: `<%`
description: treats x and y as unsigned and compares them. Returns true iff unsigned(x) < unsigned(y).
computes the floating point division
This operator computes the intersection of two sets.
This operator computes the union of two sets.
This operator computes the difference of two sets.

name: contains
description:
One should overload this proc if one wants to overload the in operator. The parameters are in reverse order! a in b is a template for contains(b, a). This is because the unification algorithm that Nim uses for overload resolution works from left to right. But for the in operator that would be the wrong direction for this piece of code:
var s: set[range['a'..'z']] = {'a'..'c'}
writeln(stdout, 'b' in s)

If in had been declared as [T](elem: T, s: set[T]) then T would have been bound to char. But s is not compatible to type set[char]! The solution is to bind T to range['a'..'z']. This is achieved by reversing the parameters for contains; in then passes its arguments in reverse order.
code: proc contains*[T](x: set[T]; y: T): bool {.magic: "InSet", noSideEffect.}

name: contains
description:
Checks if value is withing the range of s; returns true iff value >= s.a and value <= s.b
assert((1..3).contains(1) == true)
assert((1..3).contains(2) == true)
assert((1..3).contains(4) == false)
code: proc contains*[T](s: Slice[T]; value: T): bool {.noSideEffect, inline.}

name: `in`
description:
Sugar for contains
assert(1 in (1..3) == true)
assert(5 in (1..3) == false)

name: `notin`
description:
Sugar for not containing
assert(1 notin (1..3) == false)
assert(5 notin (1..3) == true)

name: `is`
description:
Checks if T is of the same type as S
proc test[T](a: T): int =
  when (T is int):
    return a
  else:
    return 0

assert(test[int](3) == 3)
assert(test[string]("xyz") == 0)
code: proc `is`*[T, S](x: T; y: S): bool {.magic: "Is", noSideEffect.}

name: `isnot`
description: Negated version of is. Equivalent to not(x is y).

name: `of`
description:
Checks if x has a type of y
assert(FloatingPointError of Exception)
assert(DivByZeroError of Exception)
code: proc `of`*[T, S](x: T; y: S): bool {.magic: "Of", noSideEffect.}

name: cmp
description: Generic compare proc. Returns a value < 0 iff x < y, a value > 0 iff x > y and 0 iff x == y. This is useful for writing generic algorithms without performance loss. This generic implementation uses the <cite>==</cite> and <cite><</cite> operators.

name: cmp
description: Compare proc for strings. More efficient than the generic version.
code: proc cmp*(x, y: string): int {.noSideEffect, procvar.}

description: turns an array into a sequence. This most often useful for constructing sequences with the array constructor: @[1, 2, 3] has the type seq[int], while [1, 2, 3] has the type array[0..2, int].
code: proc `@`*[IDX, T](a: array[IDX, T]): seq[T] {.magic: "ArrToSeq", nosideeffect.}

name: setLen
description: sets the length of s to newlen. T may be any sequence type. If the current length is greater than the new length, s will be truncated. s cannot be nil! To initialize a sequence with a size, use newSeq instead.
code:
proc setLen*[T](s: var seq[T]; newlen: int) {.magic: "SetLengthSeq", 
    noSideEffect.}

name: setLen
description: sets the length of s to newlen. If the current length is greater than the new length, s will be truncated. s cannot be nil! To initialize a string with a size, use newString instead.
code: proc setLen*(s: var string; newlen: int) {.magic: "SetLengthStr", noSideEffect.}

name: newString
description: returns a new string of length len but with uninitialized content. One needs to fill the string character after character with the index operator s[i]. This procedure exists only for optimization purposes; the same effect can be achieved with the & operator or with add.
code:
proc newString*(len: int): string {.magic: "NewString", importc: "mnewString", 
                                    noSideEffect.}

name: newStringOfCap
description: returns a new string of length 0 but with capacity cap.This procedure exists only for optimization purposes; the same effect can be achieved with the & operator or with add.
code:
proc newStringOfCap*(cap: int): string {.magic: "NewStringOfCap", 
    importc: "rawNewString", noSideEffect.}

name: `&`
description:
Concatenates x with y
assert("ab" & 'c' == "abc")
code: proc `&`*(x: string; y: char): string {.magic: "ConStrStr", noSideEffect, merge.}

name: `&`
description:
Concatenates x and y into a string
assert('a' & 'b' == "ab")
code: proc `&`*(x: char; y: char): string {.magic: "ConStrStr", noSideEffect, merge.}

name: `&`
description:
Concatenates x and y
assert("ab" & "cd" == "abcd")
code: proc `&`*(x, y: string): string {.magic: "ConStrStr", noSideEffect, merge.}

name: `&`
description:
Concatenates x with y
assert('a' & "bc" == "abc")
code: proc `&`*(x: char; y: string): string {.magic: "ConStrStr", noSideEffect, merge.}

name: add
description:
Appends y to x in place
var tmp = ""
tmp.add('a')
tmp.add('b')
assert(tmp == "ab")
code: proc add*(x: var string; y: char) {.magic: "AppendStrCh", noSideEffect.}

name: add
description:
Concatenates x and y in place
var tmp = ""
tmp.add("ab")
tmp.add("cd")
assert(tmp == "abcd")
code: proc add*(x: var string; y: string) {.magic: "AppendStrStr", noSideEffect.}

name: Endianness
description: is a type describing the endianness of a processor.

name: compileOption
description:
can be used to determine an on|off compile-time option. Example:
when compileOption("floatchecks"):
  echo "compiled with floating point NaN and Inf checks"

name: compileOption
description:
can be used to determine an enum compile-time option. Example:
when compileOption("opt", "size") and compileOption("gc", "boehm"):
  echo "compiled with optimization for size and uses Boehm's GC"
code:
proc compileOption*(option, arg: string): bool {.magic: "CompileOptionArg", 
    noSideEffect.}

name: TaintedString
description: a distinct string type that is tainted. It is an alias for string if the taint mode is not turned on. Use the -d:taintMode command line switch to turn the taint mode on.

name: QuitFailure
description: is the value that should be passed to quit to indicate failure.

name: programResult
description: modify this variable to specify the exit code of the program under normal circumstances. When the program is terminated prematurely using quit, this value is ignored.

name: quit
description:
Stops the program immediately with an exit code.

Before stopping the program the "quit procedures" are called in the opposite order they were added with addQuitProc. quit never returns and ignores any exception that may have been raised by the quit procedures. It does not call the garbage collector to free all the memory, unless a quit procedure calls GC_fullCollect.

The proc quit(QuitSuccess) is called implicitly when your nim program finishes without incident. A raised unhandled exception is equivalent to calling quit(QuitFailure).

Note that this is a runtime call and using quit inside a macro won't have any compile time effect. If you need to stop the compiler inside a macro, use the error or fatal pragmas.
code:
proc quit*(errorcode: int = QuitSuccess) {.magic: "Exit", importc: "exit", 
    header: "<stdlib.h>", noReturn.}

name: add
code: proc add*[T](x: var seq[T]; y: T) {.magic: "AppendSeqElem", noSideEffect.}

name: add
description: Generic proc for adding a data item y to a container x. For containers that have an order, add means append. New generic containers should also call their adding proc add for consistency. Generic code becomes much easier to write if the Nim naming scheme is respected.
code: proc add*[T](x: var seq[T]; y: openArray[T]) {.noSideEffect.}

name: shallowCopy
description: use this instead of = for a shallow copy. The shallow copy only changes the semantics for sequences and strings (and types which contain those). Be careful with the changed semantics though! There is a reason why the default assignment does a deep copy of sequences and strings.
code: proc shallowCopy*[T](x: var T; y: T) {.noSideEffect, magic: "ShallowCopy".}

name: del
description: deletes the item at index i by putting x[high(x)] into position i. This is an O(1) operation.
code: proc del*[T](x: var seq[T]; i: int) {.noSideEffect.}

name: delete
description: deletes the item at index i by moving x[i+1..] by one position. This is an O(n) operation.
code: proc delete*[T](x: var seq[T]; i: int) {.noSideEffect.}

name: insert
description: inserts <cite>item</cite> into <cite>x</cite> at position <cite>i</cite>.
code: proc insert*[T](x: var seq[T]; item: T; i = 0) {.noSideEffect.}

name: repr
description: takes any Nim variable and returns its string representation. It works even for complex data graphs with cycles. This is a great debugging tool.

name: BiggestFloat
description: is an alias for the biggest floating point type the Nim compiler supports. Currently this is float64, but it is platform-dependant in general.

name: culong
description: This is the same as the type unsigned long in C.

name: PInt32
description: an alias for ptr int32

name: toFloat
description: converts an integer i into a float. If the conversion fails, EInvalidValue is raised. However, on most platforms the conversion cannot fail.
code:
proc toFloat*(i: int): float {.magic: "ToFloat", noSideEffect, 
                               importc: "toFloat".}

name: toBiggestFloat
description: converts an biggestint i into a biggestfloat. If the conversion fails, EInvalidValue is raised. However, on most platforms the conversion cannot fail.
code:
proc toBiggestFloat*(i: BiggestInt): BiggestFloat {.magic: "ToBiggestFloat", 
    noSideEffect, importc: "toBiggestFloat".}

name: toInt
description: converts a floating point number f into an int. Conversion rounds f if it does not contain an integer value. If the conversion fails (because f is infinite for example), EInvalidValue is raised.
code: proc toInt*(f: float): int {.magic: "ToInt", noSideEffect, importc: "toInt".}

name: toBiggestInt
description: converts a biggestfloat f into a biggestint. Conversion rounds f if it does not contain an integer value. If the conversion fails (because f is infinite for example), EInvalidValue is raised.
code:
proc toBiggestInt*(f: BiggestFloat): BiggestInt {.magic: "ToBiggestInt", 
    noSideEffect, importc: "toBiggestInt".}

name: addQuitProc
description:
Adds/registers a quit procedure.

Each call to addQuitProc registers another quit procedure. Up to 30 procedures can be registered. They are executed on a last-in, first-out basis (that is, the last function registered is the first to be executed). addQuitProc raises an EOutOfIndex exception if QuitProc cannot be registered.

name: copy
code:
proc copy*(s: string; first = 0): string {.magic: "CopyStr", importc: "copyStr", 
    noSideEffect, deprecated.}

name: copy
description: copies a slice of s into a new string and returns this new string. The bounds first and last denote the indices of the first and last characters that shall be copied. If last is omitted, it is treated as high(s). Deprecated since version 0.8.12: Use substr instead.
code:
proc copy*(s: string; first, last: int): string {.magic: "CopyStrLast", 
    importc: "copyStrLast", noSideEffect, deprecated.}

name: substr
code:
proc substr*(s: string; first = 0): string {.magic: "CopyStr", 
    importc: "copyStr", noSideEffect.}

name: substr
description: copies a slice of s into a new string and returns this new string. The bounds first and last denote the indices of the first and last characters that shall be copied. If last is omitted, it is treated as high(s). If last >= s.len, s.len is used instead: This means substr can also be used to cut or limit a string's length.
code:
proc substr*(s: string; first, last: int): string {.magic: "CopyStrLast", 
    importc: "copyStrLast", noSideEffect.}

name: zeroMem
description: overwrites the contents of the memory at p with the value 0. Exactly size bytes will be overwritten. Like any procedure dealing with raw memory this is unsafe.
code: proc zeroMem*(p: pointer; size: int) {.importc, noDecl, benign.}

name: copyMem
description: copies the contents from the memory at source to the memory at dest. Exactly size bytes will be copied. The memory regions may not overlap. Like any procedure dealing with raw memory this is unsafe.
code:
proc copyMem*(dest, source: pointer; size: int) {.importc: "memcpy", 
    header: "<string.h>", benign.}

name: moveMem
description: copies the contents from the memory at source to the memory at dest. Exactly size bytes will be copied. The memory regions may overlap, moveMem handles this case appropriately and is thus somewhat more safe than copyMem. Like any procedure dealing with raw memory this is still unsafe, though.
code:
proc moveMem*(dest, source: pointer; size: int) {.importc: "memmove", 
    header: "<string.h>", benign.}

name: equalMem
description: compares the memory blocks a and b. size bytes will be compared. If the blocks are equal, true is returned, false otherwise. Like any procedure dealing with raw memory this is unsafe.
code:
proc equalMem*(a, b: pointer; size: int): bool {.importc: "equalMem", noDecl, 
    noSideEffect.}

name: alloc
description: allocates a new memory block with at least size bytes. The block has to be freed with realloc(block, 0) or dealloc(block). The block is not initialized, so reading from it before writing to it is undefined behaviour! The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use allocShared to allocate from a shared heap.
code: proc alloc*(size: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, tags: [], benign.}

name: createU
description: allocates a new memory block with at least T.sizeof * size bytes. The block has to be freed with resize(block, 0) or free(block). The block is not initialized, so reading from it before writing to it is undefined behaviour! The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use createSharedU to allocate from a shared heap.
code: proc createU*(T: typedesc; size = 1.Positive): ptr T {.inline, benign.}

name: alloc0
description: allocates a new memory block with at least size bytes. The block has to be freed with realloc(block, 0) or dealloc(block). The block is initialized with all bytes containing zero, so it is somewhat safer than alloc. The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use allocShared0 to allocate from a shared heap.
code: proc alloc0*(size: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, tags: [], benign.}

name: create
description: allocates a new memory block with at least T.sizeof * size bytes. The block has to be freed with resize(block, 0) or free(block). The block is initialized with all bytes containing zero, so it is somewhat safer than createU. The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use createShared to allocate from a shared heap.
code: proc create*(T: typedesc; size = 1.Positive): ptr T {.inline, benign.}

name: realloc
description: grows or shrinks a given memory block. If p is nil then a new memory block is returned. In either way the block has at least newSize bytes. If newSize == 0 and p is not nil realloc calls dealloc(p). In other cases the block has to be freed with dealloc. The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use reallocShared to reallocate from a shared heap.
code: proc realloc*(p: pointer; newSize: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, tags: [], benign.}

name: resize
description: grows or shrinks a given memory block. If p is nil then a new memory block is returned. In either way the block has at least T.sizeof * newSize bytes. If newSize == 0 and p is not nil resize calls free(p). In other cases the block has to be freed with free. The allocated memory belongs to its allocating thread! Use resizeShared to reallocate from a shared heap.
code: proc resize*[T](p: ptr T; newSize: Natural): ptr T {.inline, benign.}

name: dealloc
description: frees the memory allocated with alloc, alloc0 or realloc. This procedure is dangerous! If one forgets to free the memory a leak occurs; if one tries to access freed memory (or just freeing it twice!) a core dump may happen or other memory may be corrupted. The freed memory must belong to its allocating thread! Use deallocShared to deallocate from a shared heap.
code: proc dealloc*(p: pointer) {.noconv, rtl, tags: [], benign.}

name: allocShared
description: allocates a new memory block on the shared heap with at least size bytes. The block has to be freed with reallocShared(block, 0) or deallocShared(block). The block is not initialized, so reading from it before writing to it is undefined behaviour!
code: proc allocShared*(size: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, benign.}

name: createSharedU
description: allocates a new memory block on the shared heap with at least T.sizeof * size bytes. The block has to be freed with resizeShared(block, 0) or freeShared(block). The block is not initialized, so reading from it before writing to it is undefined behaviour!
code: proc createSharedU*(T: typedesc; size = 1.Positive): ptr T {.inline, benign.}

name: allocShared0
description: allocates a new memory block on the shared heap with at least size bytes. The block has to be freed with reallocShared(block, 0) or deallocShared(block). The block is initialized with all bytes containing zero, so it is somewhat safer than allocShared.
code: proc allocShared0*(size: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, benign.}

name: createShared
description: allocates a new memory block on the shared heap with at least T.sizeof * size bytes. The block has to be freed with resizeShared(block, 0) or freeShared(block). The block is initialized with all bytes containing zero, so it is somewhat safer than createSharedU.
code: proc createShared*(T: typedesc; size = 1.Positive): ptr T {.inline.}

name: reallocShared
description: grows or shrinks a given memory block on the heap. If p is nil then a new memory block is returned. In either way the block has at least newSize bytes. If newSize == 0 and p is not nil reallocShared calls deallocShared(p). In other cases the block has to be freed with deallocShared.
code: proc reallocShared*(p: pointer; newSize: int): pointer {.noconv, rtl, benign.}

name: resizeShared
description: grows or shrinks a given memory block on the heap. If p is nil then a new memory block is returned. In either way the block has at least T.sizeof * newSize bytes. If newSize == 0 and p is not nil resizeShared calls freeShared(p). In other cases the block has to be freed with freeShared.
code: proc resizeShared*[T](p: ptr T; newSize: Natural): ptr T {.inline.}

name: deallocShared
description: frees the memory allocated with allocShared, allocShared0 or reallocShared. This procedure is dangerous! If one forgets to free the memory a leak occurs; if one tries to access freed memory (or just freeing it twice!) a core dump may happen or other memory may be corrupted.

name: freeShared
description: frees the memory allocated with createShared, createSharedU or resizeShared. This procedure is dangerous! If one forgets to free the memory a leak occurs; if one tries to access freed memory (or just freeing it twice!) a core dump may happen or other memory may be corrupted.

name: swap
description: swaps the values a and b. This is often more efficient than tmp = a; a = b; b = tmp. Particularly useful for sorting algorithms.
code: proc swap*[T](a, b: var T) {.magic: "Swap", noSideEffect.}

name: `>=%`
description: treats x and y as unsigned and compares them. Returns true iff unsigned(x) >= unsigned(y).

name: `>%`
description: treats x and y as unsigned and compares them. Returns true iff unsigned(x) > unsigned(y).
The stringify operator for an integer argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a decimal string.
The stringify operator for an integer argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a decimal string.
The stringify operator for an unsigned integer argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a decimal string.
The stringify operator for a float argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a decimal string.
The stringify operator for a boolean argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to the string "false" or "true".
The stringify operator for a character argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a string.
The stringify operator for a CString argument. Returns <cite>x</cite> converted to a string.
The stringify operator for a string argument. Returns x as it is. This operator is useful for generic code, so that $expr also works if expr is already a string.

The stringify operator for an enumeration argument. This works for any enumeration type thanks to compiler magic. If a $ operator for a concrete enumeration is provided, this is used instead. (In other words: Overwriting is possible.)

name: getRefcount
code: proc getRefcount*[T](x: ref T): int {.importc: "getRefcount", noSideEffect.}

name: getRefcount
description: retrieves the reference count of an heap-allocated object. The value is implementation-dependent.

name: NimVersion
description: is the version of Nim as a string.

name: getOccupiedMem
description: returns the number of bytes that are owned by the process and hold data.

name: getFreeMem
description: returns the number of bytes that are owned by the process, but do not hold any meaningful data.

name: getTotalMem
description: returns the number of bytes that are owned by the process.

name: getOccupiedSharedMem
description: returns the number of bytes that are owned by the process on the shared heap and hold data. This is only available when threads are enabled.

name: getFreeSharedMem
description: returns the number of bytes that are owned by the process on the shared heap, but do not hold any meaningful data. This is only available when threads are enabled.

name: getTotalSharedMem
description: returns the number of bytes on the shared heap that are owned by the process. This is only available when threads are enabled.

name: countdown
description: Counts from ordinal value <cite>a</cite> down to <cite>b</cite> with the given step count. <cite>T</cite> may be any ordinal type, <cite>step</cite> may only be positive.
code: iterator countdown*[T](a, b: T; step = 1): T {.inline.}

name: countup
description: Counts from ordinal value <cite>a</cite> up to <cite>b</cite> with the given step count. <cite>S</cite>, <cite>T</cite> may be any ordinal type, <cite>step</cite> may only be positive.
code: iterator countup*[S, T](a: S; b: T; step = 1): T {.inline.}

description: An alias for <cite>countup</cite>.
code: iterator `..`*[S, T](a: S; b: T): T {.inline.}

description: parallel loop iterator. Same as .. but the loop may run in parallel. annotation is an additional annotation for the code generator to use. Note that the compiler maps that to the #pragma omp parallel for construct of OpenMP and as such isn't aware of the parallelism in your code! Be careful! Later versions of || will get proper support by Nim's code generator and GC.
code:
iterator `||`*[S, T](a: S; b: T; annotation = ""): T {.inline, 
    magic: "OmpParFor", sideEffect.}

name: min
code: proc min*(x, y: int): int {.magic: "MinI", noSideEffect.}

name: min
code: proc min*(x, y: int8): int8 {.magic: "MinI", noSideEffect.}

name: min
code: proc min*(x, y: int16): int16 {.magic: "MinI", noSideEffect.}

name: min
code: proc min*(x, y: int32): int32 {.magic: "MinI", noSideEffect.}

name: min
description: The minimum value of two integers.
code: proc min*(x, y: int64): int64 {.magic: "MinI64", noSideEffect.}

name: min
description: The minimum value of x. T needs to have a < operator.

name: max
code: proc max*(x, y: int): int {.magic: "MaxI", noSideEffect.}

name: max
code: proc max*(x, y: int8): int8 {.magic: "MaxI", noSideEffect.}

name: max
code: proc max*(x, y: int16): int16 {.magic: "MaxI", noSideEffect.}

name: max
code: proc max*(x, y: int32): int32 {.magic: "MaxI", noSideEffect.}

name: max
description: The maximum value of two integers.
code: proc max*(x, y: int64): int64 {.magic: "MaxI64", noSideEffect.}

name: max
description: The maximum value of x. T needs to have a < operator.

name: min
code: proc min*(x, y: float): float {.magic: "MinF64", noSideEffect.}

name: max
code: proc max*(x, y: float): float {.magic: "MaxF64", noSideEffect.}

name: clamp
description:
limits the value x within the interval [a, b]
assert((1.4).clamp(0.0, 1.0) == 1.0)
assert((0.5).clamp(0.0, 1.0) == 0.5)
code: proc clamp*[T](x, a, b: T): T

name: items
description: iterates over each item of <cite>a</cite>.

name: items
description: iterates over each item of <cite>a</cite>.
code: iterator items*[IX, T](a: array[IX, T]): T {.inline.}

name: items
description: iterates over each element of <cite>a</cite>. <cite>items</cite> iterates only over the elements that are really in the set (and not over the ones the set is able to hold).

name: items
description: iterates over each item of <cite>a</cite>.

name: items
description: iterates over the values of the enum E.

name: pairs
description: iterates over each item of a. Yields (index, a[index]) pairs.
code: iterator pairs*[T](a: openArray[T]): tuple[key: int, val: T] {.inline.}

name: pairs
description: iterates over each item of a. Yields (index, a[index]) pairs.
code: iterator pairs*[IX, T](a: array[IX, T]): tuple[key: IX, val: T] {.inline.}

name: pairs
description: iterates over each item of a. Yields (index, a[index]) pairs.
code: iterator pairs*[T](a: seq[T]): tuple[key: int, val: T] {.inline.}

name: pairs
description: iterates over each item of a. Yields (index, a[index]) pairs.
code: iterator pairs*(a: string): tuple[key: int, val: char] {.inline.}

name: isNil
code: proc isNil*[T](x: ref T): bool {.noSideEffect, magic: "IsNil".}

name: isNil
code: proc isNil*[T](x: ptr T): bool {.noSideEffect, magic: "IsNil".}

name: isNil
description: Fast check whether x is nil. This is sometimes more efficient than == nil.
code: proc isNil*[T: proc](x: T): bool {.noSideEffect, magic: "IsNil".}
proc `==`*[I, T](x, y: array[I, T]): bool

description: turns an openarray into a sequence. This is not as efficient as turning a fixed length array into a sequence as it always copies every element of <cite>a</cite>.

name: `&`
description:
Concatenates two sequences. Requires copying of the sequences.
assert(@[1, 2, 3, 4] & @[5, 6] == @[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])

name: `&`
description:
Appends element y to the end of the sequence. Requires copying of the sequence
assert(@[1, 2, 3] & 4 == @[1, 2, 3, 4])

name: `&`
description:
Prepends the element x to the beginning of the sequence. Requires copying of the sequence
assert(1 & @[2, 3, 4] == @[1, 2, 3, 4])
Generic equals operator for sequences: relies on a equals operator for the element type <cite>T</cite>.

name: find
description: Returns the first index of <cite>item</cite> in <cite>a</cite> or -1 if not found. This requires appropriate <cite>items</cite> and <cite>==</cite> operations to work.
code: proc find*[T, S](a: T; item: S): int {.inline.}

name: contains
description: Returns true if item is in a or false if not found. This is a shortcut for find(a, item) >= 0.
code: proc contains*[T](a: openArray[T]; item: T): bool {.inline.}

name: pop
description: returns the last item of s and decreases s.len by one. This treats s as a stack and implements the common pop operation.
code: proc pop*[T](s: var seq[T]): T {.inline, noSideEffect.}

name: each
description:
The well-known map operation from functional programming. Applies op to every item in data and returns the result as a sequence.

Deprecated since version 0.9: Use the map proc instead.
code:
proc each*[T, S](data: openArray[T]; op: proc (x: T): S {.closure.}): seq[S] {.
    deprecated.}

name: each
description:
The well-known map operation from functional programming. Applies op to every item in data modifying it directly.

Deprecated since version 0.9: Use the map proc instead.
code:
proc each*[T](data: var openArray[T]; op: proc (x: var T) {.closure.}) {.
    deprecated.}

name: map
description:
Returns a new sequence with the results of op applied to every item in data.

Since the input is not modified you can use this version of map to transform the type of the elements in the input sequence. Example:

let
  a = @[1, 2, 3, 4]
  b = map(a, proc(x: int): string = $x)
assert b == @["1", "2", "3", "4"]
code: proc map*[T, S](data: openArray[T]; op: proc (x: T): S {.closure.}): seq[S]

name: map
description:
Applies op to every item in data modifying it directly.

Note that this version of map requires your input and output types to be the same, since they are modified in-place. Example:

var a = @["1", "2", "3", "4"]
echo repr(a)
# --> ["1", "2", "3", "4"]
map(a, proc(x: var string) = x &= "42")
echo repr(a)
# --> ["142", "242", "342", "442"]
code: proc map*[T](data: var openArray[T]; op: proc (x: var T) {.closure.})

name: fields
description: iterates over every field of <cite>x</cite>. Warning: This really transforms the 'for' and unrolls the loop. The current implementation also has a bug that affects symbol binding in the loop body.
code:
iterator fields*[T: tuple |
    object](x: T): RootObj {.magic: "Fields", noSideEffect.}

name: fields
description: iterates over every field of <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>. Warning: This is really transforms the 'for' and unrolls the loop. The current implementation also has a bug that affects symbol binding in the loop body.

name: fieldPairs
description:
Iterates over every field of x returning their name and value.

When you iterate over objects with different field types you have to use the compile time when instead of a runtime if to select the code you want to run for each type. To perform the comparison use the is operator. Example:

type
  Custom = object
    foo: string
    bar: bool

proc `$`(x: Custom): string =
  result = "Custom:"
  for name, value in x.fieldPairs:
    when value is bool:
      result.add("\n\t" & name & " is " & $value)
    else:
      if value.isNil:
        result.add("\n\t" & name & " (nil)")
      else:
        result.add("\n\t" & name & " '" & value & "'")

Another way to do the same without when is to leave the task of picking the appropriate code to a secondary proc which you overload for each field type and pass the value to.

Warning: This really transforms the 'for' and unrolls the loop. The current implementation also has a bug that affects symbol binding in the loop body.
code:
iterator fieldPairs*[T: tuple |
    object](x: T): RootObj {.magic: "FieldPairs", noSideEffect.}

name: fieldPairs
description: iterates over every field of <cite>x</cite> and <cite>y</cite>. Warning: This really transforms the 'for' and unrolls the loop. The current implementation also has a bug that affects symbol binding in the loop body.
generic == operator for tuples that is lifted from the components of x and y.
code:
proc `==`*[T: tuple |
    object](x, y: T): bool

name: `<=`
description: generic <= operator for tuples that is lifted from the components of x and y. This implementation uses cmp.

name: `<`
description: generic < operator for tuples that is lifted from the components of x and y. This implementation uses cmp.

generic $ operator for tuples that is lifted from the components of x. Example:
$(23, 45) == "(23, 45)"
$() == "()"

generic $ operator for sets that is lifted from the components of x. Example:
${23, 45} == "{23, 45}"

generic $ operator for seqs that is lifted from the components of x. Example:
$(@[23, 45]) == "@[23, 45]"

name: GC_disable
description: disables the GC. If called n-times, n calls to <cite>GC_enable</cite> are needed to reactivate the GC. Note that in most circumstances one should only disable the mark and sweep phase with <cite>GC_disableMarkAndSweep</cite>.

name: GC_enable
description: enables the GC again.

name: GC_fullCollect
description: forces a full garbage collection pass. Ordinary code does not need to call this (and should not).

name: GC_Strategy
description: the strategy the GC should use for the application
code:
GC_Strategy* = enum 
  gcThroughput,               ## optimize for throughput
  gcResponsiveness,           ## optimize for responsiveness (default)
  gcOptimizeTime,             ## optimize for speed
  gcOptimizeSpace             ## optimize for memory footprint

name: GC_setStrategy
description: tells the GC the desired strategy for the application. Deprecated since version 0.8.14. This has always been a nop.

name: GC_disableMarkAndSweep
description: the current implementation uses a reference counting garbage collector with a seldomly run mark and sweep phase to free cycles. The mark and sweep phase may take a long time and is not needed if the application does not create cycles. Thus the mark and sweep phase can be deactivated and activated separately from the rest of the GC.

name: GC_getStatistics
description: returns an informative string about the GC's activity. This may be useful for tweaking.

name: GC_ref
description: marks the object <cite>x</cite> as referenced, so that it will not be freed until it is unmarked via <cite>GC_unref</cite>. If called n-times for the same object <cite>x</cite>, n calls to <cite>GC_unref</cite> are needed to unmark <cite>x</cite>.

name: GC_unref
description: see the documentation of <cite>GC_ref</cite>.

name: accumulateResult
description: helps to convert an iterator to a proc.

name: outOfMemHook
description:
set this variable to provide a procedure that should be called in case of an out of memory event. The standard handler writes an error message and terminates the program. outOfMemHook can be used to raise an exception in case of OOM like so:
var gOutOfMem: ref EOutOfMemory
new(gOutOfMem) # need to be allocated *before* OOM really happened!
gOutOfMem.msg = "out of memory"

proc handleOOM() =
  raise gOutOfMem

system.outOfMemHook = handleOOM

If the handler does not raise an exception, ordinary control flow continues and the program is terminated.

name: TFrame
description: the frame itself
code:
TFrame* {.importc, nodecl, final.} = object 
  prev*: PFrame               ## previous frame; used for chaining the call stack
  procname*: cstring          ## name of the proc that is currently executing
  line*: int                  ## line number of the proc that is currently executing
  filename*: cstring          ## filename of the proc that is currently executing
  len*: int16                 ## length of the inspectable slots
  calldepth*: int16           ## used for max call depth checking

name: add
code: proc add*(x: var string; y: cstring) {.asmNoStackFrame.}

name: add
code: proc add*(x: var cstring; y: cstring) {.magic: "AppendStrStr".}

name: echo
description:
Writes and flushes the parameters to the standard output.

Special built-in that takes a variable number of arguments. Each argument is converted to a string via $, so it works for user-defined types that have an overloaded $ operator. It is roughly equivalent to writeln(stdout, x); flushFile(stdout), but available for the JavaScript target too.

Unlike other IO operations this is guaranteed to be thread-safe as echo is very often used for debugging convenience. If you want to use echo inside a proc without side effects you can use debugEcho instead.

name: debugEcho
description: Same as echo, but as a special semantic rule, debugEcho pretends to be free of side effects, so that it can be used for debugging routines marked as noSideEffect.
code:
proc debugEcho*(x: varargs[expr, `$`]) {.magic: "Echo", noSideEffect, tags: [], 
    raises: [].}

name: newException
description: creates an exception object of type exceptn and sets its msg field to message. Returns the new exception object.
code: template newException*(exceptn: typedesc; message: string): expr

name: getTypeInfo
description: get type information for <cite>x</cite>. Ordinary code should not use this, but the <cite>typeinfo</cite> module instead.
code: proc getTypeInfo*[T](x: T): pointer {.magic: "GetTypeInfo", gcsafe, locks: 0.}

name: abs
description: returns the absolute value of x. If x is low(x) (that is -MININT for its type), an overflow exception is thrown (if overflow checking is turned on).

name: FileHandle
description: type that represents an OS file handle; this is useful for low-level file access

name: stderr
description: The standard error stream.

name: open
description:
Opens a file named filename with given mode.

Default mode is readonly. Returns true iff the file could be opened. This throws no exception if the file could not be opened.
code:
proc open*(f: var File; filename: string; mode: FileMode = fmRead; 
           bufSize: int = - 1): bool {.tags: [], benign.}

name: open
description:
Creates a TFile from a filehandle with given mode.

Default mode is readonly. Returns true iff the file could be opened.
code:
proc open*(f: var File; filehandle: FileHandle; mode: FileMode = fmRead): bool {.
    tags: [], benign.}

name: open
description:
Opens a file named filename with given mode.

Default mode is readonly. Raises an IO exception if the file could not be opened.
code: proc open*(filename: string; mode: FileMode = fmRead; bufSize: int = - 1): File

name: reopen
description:
reopens the file f with given filename and mode. This is often used to redirect the stdin, stdout or stderr file variables.

Default mode is readonly. Returns true iff the file could be reopened.
code:
proc reopen*(f: File; filename: string; mode: FileMode = fmRead): bool {.
    tags: [], benign.}

name: close
description: Closes the file.

name: endOfFile
description: Returns true iff <cite>f</cite> is at the end.

name: readChar
description: Reads a single character from the stream <cite>f</cite>.
code:
proc readChar*(f: File): char {.importc: "fgetc", header: "<stdio.h>", 
                                tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

name: flushFile
description: Flushes <cite>f</cite>'s buffer.

name: readAll
description:
Reads all data from the stream file.

Raises an IO exception in case of an error. It is an error if the current file position is not at the beginning of the file.

name: readFile
description:
Opens a file named filename for reading.

Then calls readAll and closes the file afterwards. Returns the string. Raises an IO exception in case of an error. If you need to call this inside a compile time macro you can use staticRead.

name: writeFile
description: Opens a file named <cite>filename</cite> for writing. Then writes the <cite>content</cite> completely to the file and closes the file afterwards. Raises an IO exception in case of an error.

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; r: float32) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; i: int) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; i: BiggestInt) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; r: BiggestFloat) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; s: string) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; b: bool) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; c: char) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
code: proc write*(f: File; c: cstring) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: write
description: Writes a value to the file <cite>f</cite>. May throw an IO exception.
code: proc write*(f: File; a: varargs[string, `$`]) {.tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: readLine
description: reads a line of text from the file f. May throw an IO exception. A line of text may be delimited by CR, LF or CRLF. The newline character(s) are not part of the returned string.

name: readLine
description: reads a line of text from the file f into line. line must not be nil! May throw an IO exception. A line of text may be delimited by CR, LF or CRLF. The newline character(s) are not part of the returned string. Returns false if the end of the file has been reached, true otherwise. If false is returned line contains no new data.
code:
proc readLine*(f: File; line: var TaintedString): bool {.tags: [ReadIOEffect], 
    benign.}

name: writeln
description: writes the values <cite>x</cite> to <cite>f</cite> and then writes "n". May throw an IO exception.
code:
proc writeln*[Ty](f: File; x: varargs[Ty, `$`]) {.inline, tags: [WriteIOEffect], 
    gcsafe, locks: 0.}

name: getFileSize
description: retrieves the file size (in bytes) of <cite>f</cite>.

name: readBytes
description: reads len bytes into the buffer a starting at a[start]. Returns the actual number of bytes that have been read which may be less than len (if not as many bytes are remaining), but not greater.
code:
proc readBytes*(f: File; a: var openArray[int8]; start, len: int): int {.
    tags: [ReadIOEffect], benign.}

name: readChars
description: reads len bytes into the buffer a starting at a[start]. Returns the actual number of bytes that have been read which may be less than len (if not as many bytes are remaining), but not greater.
code:
proc readChars*(f: File; a: var openArray[char]; start, len: int): int {.
    tags: [ReadIOEffect], benign.}

name: readBuffer
description: reads <cite>len</cite> bytes into the buffer pointed to by <cite>buffer</cite>. Returns the actual number of bytes that have been read which may be less than <cite>len</cite> (if not as many bytes are remaining), but not greater.
code:
proc readBuffer*(f: File; buffer: pointer; len: int): int {.
    tags: [ReadIOEffect], benign.}

name: writeBytes
description: writes the bytes of a[start..start+len-1] to the file f. Returns the number of actual written bytes, which may be less than len in case of an error.
code:
proc writeBytes*(f: File; a: openArray[int8]; start, len: int): int {.
    tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: writeChars
description: writes the bytes of a[start..start+len-1] to the file f. Returns the number of actual written bytes, which may be less than len in case of an error.
code:
proc writeChars*(f: File; a: openArray[char]; start, len: int): int {.
    tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: writeBuffer
description: writes the bytes of buffer pointed to by the parameter <cite>buffer</cite> to the file <cite>f</cite>. Returns the number of actual written bytes, which may be less than <cite>len</cite> in case of an error.
code:
proc writeBuffer*(f: File; buffer: pointer; len: int): int {.
    tags: [WriteIOEffect], benign.}

name: setFilePos
description: sets the position of the file pointer that is used for read/write operations. The file's first byte has the index zero.

name: getFilePos
description: retrieves the current position of the file pointer that is used to read from the file <cite>f</cite>. The file's first byte has the index zero.

name: getFileHandle
description: returns the OS file handle of the file f. This is only useful for platform specific programming.

name: cstringArrayToSeq
description: converts a cstringArray to a seq[string]. a is supposed to be of length len.
code: proc cstringArrayToSeq*(a: cstringArray; len: int): seq[string]

name: cstringArrayToSeq
description: converts a cstringArray to a seq[string]. a is supposed to be terminated by nil.

name: allocCStringArray
description: creates a NULL terminated cstringArray from <cite>a</cite>. The result has to be freed with <cite>deallocCStringArray</cite> after it's not needed anymore.

name: deallocCStringArray
description: frees a NULL terminated cstringArray.

name: atomicInc
description: atomic increment of <cite>memLoc</cite>. Returns the value after the operation.
code: proc atomicInc*(memLoc: var int; x: int = 1): int {.inline, discardable, benign.}

name: atomicDec
description: atomic decrement of <cite>memLoc</cite>. Returns the value after the operation.
code: proc atomicDec*(memLoc: var int; x: int = 1): int {.inline, discardable, benign.}

name: setControlCHook
description: allows you to override the behaviour of your application when CTRL+C is pressed. Only one such hook is supported.

name: writeStackTrace
description: writes the current stack trace to stderr. This is only works for debug builds.

name: getStackTrace
description: gets the current stack trace. This only works for debug builds.

name: getStackTrace
description: gets the stack trace associated with e, which is the stack that lead to the raise statement. This only works for debug builds.

name: lines
description:
Iterates over any line in the file named filename.

If the file does not exist EIO is raised. The trailing newline character(s) are removed from the iterated lines. Example:

import strutils

proc transformLetters(filename: string) =
  var buffer = ""
  for line in filename.lines:
    buffer.add(line.replace("a", "0") & '\x0A')
  writeFile(filename, buffer)

name: lines
description:
Iterate over any line in the file f.

The trailing newline character(s) are removed from the iterated lines. Example:

proc countZeros(filename: File): tuple[lines, zeros: int] =
  for line in filename.lines:
    for letter in line:
      if letter == '0':
        result.zeros += 1
    result.lines += 1

name: getCurrentException
description: retrieves the current exception; if there is none, nil is returned.
code: proc getCurrentException*(): ref Exception {.compilerRtl, inl, benign.}

name: getCurrentExceptionMsg
description: retrieves the error message that was attached to the current exception; if there is none, "" is returned.

name: onRaise
description: can be used in a try statement to setup a Lisp-like condition system: This prevents the 'raise' statement to raise an exception but instead calls action. If action returns false, the exception has been handled and does not propagate further through the call stack.
code: proc onRaise*(action: proc (e: ref Exception): bool {.closure.})

name: setCurrentException
description:
sets the current exception.

Warning: Only use this if you know what you are doing.

name: likely
description:
Hints the optimizer that val is likely going to be true.

You can use this proc to decorate a branch condition. On certain platforms this can help the processor predict better which branch is going to be run. Example:

for value in inputValues:
  if likely(value <= 100):
    process(value)
  else:
    echo "Value too big!"
code: proc likely*(val: bool): bool {.importc: "likely", nodecl, nosideeffect.}

name: unlikely
description:
Hints the optimizer that val is likely going to be false.

You can use this proc to decorate a branch condition. On certain platforms this can help the processor predict better which branch is going to be run. Example:

for value in inputValues:
  if unlikely(value > 100):
    echo "Value too big!"
  else:
    process(value)
code: proc unlikely*(val: bool): bool {.importc: "unlikely", nodecl, nosideeffect.}

name: rawProc
description: retrieves the raw proc pointer of the closure <cite>x</cite>. This is useful for interfacing closures with C.
code: proc rawProc*[T: proc](x: T): pointer {.noSideEffect, inline.}

name: rawEnv
description: retrieves the raw environment pointer of the closure <cite>x</cite>. This is useful for interfacing closures with C.
code: proc rawEnv*[T: proc](x: T): pointer {.noSideEffect, inline.}

name: finished
description: can be used to determine if a first class iterator has finished.
code: proc finished*[T: proc](x: T): bool {.noSideEffect, inline.}

name: quit
description: a shorthand for echo(errormsg); quit(errorcode).
integer division that results in a float.
slice operation for strings. Negative indexes are supported.

slice assignment for strings. Negative indexes are supported. If b.len is not exactly the number of elements that are referred to by x, a splice is performed:
var s = "abcdef"
s[1 .. -2] = "xyz"
assert s == "axyzf"
code: proc `[]=`*(s: var string; x: Slice[int]; b: string)

description: slice operation for arrays. Negative indexes are not supported because the array might have negative bounds.
code: proc `[]`*[Idx, T](a: array[Idx, T]; x: Slice[int]): seq[T]

description: slice assignment for arrays. Negative indexes are not supported because the array might have negative bounds.
code: proc `[]=`*[Idx, T](a: var array[Idx, T]; x: Slice[int]; b: openArray[T])

description: slice operation for arrays. Negative indexes are not supported because the array might have negative bounds.
code: proc `[]`*[Idx, T](a: array[Idx, T]; x: Slice[Idx]): seq[T]

description: slice assignment for arrays. Negative indexes are not supported because the array might have negative bounds.
code: proc `[]=`*[Idx, T](a: var array[Idx, T]; x: Slice[Idx]; b: openArray[T])

description: slice operation for sequences. Negative indexes are supported.
slice assignment for sequences. Negative indexes are supported. If b.len is not exactly the number of elements that are referred to by x, a splice is performed.
code: proc `[]=`*[T](s: var seq[T]; x: Slice[int]; b: openArray[T])

name: slurp
description: This is an alias for staticRead.

name: staticRead
description:
Compile-time readFile proc for easy resource embedding:
const myResource = staticRead"mydatafile.bin"

slurp is an alias for staticRead.

name: gorge
description: This is an alias for staticExec.

name: staticExec
description:
Executes an external process at compile-time. if input is not an empty string, it will be passed as a standard input to the executed program.
const buildInfo = "Revision " & staticExec("git rev-parse HEAD") &
                  "\nCompiled on " & staticExec("uname -v")

gorge is an alias for staticExec. Note that you can use this proc inside a pragma like passC or passL.
Increments an ordinal
code:
proc `+=`*[T: SomeOrdinal | uint | uint64](x: var T; y: T) {.magic: "Inc", 
    noSideEffect.}

description: Decrements an ordinal
code:
proc `-=`*[T: SomeOrdinal | uint | uint64](x: var T; y: T) {.magic: "Dec", 
    noSideEffect.}

description: Binary <cite>*=</cite> operator for ordinals
code:
proc `*=`*[T: SomeOrdinal | uint | uint64](x: var T; y: T) {.inline, 
    noSideEffect.}

description: Increments in placee a floating point number
code: proc `+=`*[T: float | float32 | float64](x: var T; y: T) {.inline, noSideEffect.}

description: Decrements in place a floating point number
code: proc `-=`*[T: float | float32 | float64](x: var T; y: T) {.inline, noSideEffect.}

description: Multiplies in place a floating point number
code: proc `*=`*[T: float | float32 | float64](x: var T; y: T) {.inline, noSideEffect.}

description: Divides in place a floating point number
code: proc `/=`*(x: var float64; y: float64) {.inline, noSideEffect.}

description: Divides in place a floating point number
code: proc `/=`*[T: float | float32](x: var T; y: T) {.inline, noSideEffect.}

name: `&=`
code: proc `&=`*(x: var string; y: string) {.magic: "AppendStrStr", noSideEffect.}

name: astToStr
description: converts the AST of <cite>x</cite> into a string representation. This is very useful for debugging.

name: instantiationInfo
description:
provides access to the compiler's instantiation stack line information.

This proc is mostly useful for meta programming (eg. assert template) to retrieve information about the current filename and line number. Example:

import strutils

template testException(exception, code: expr): stmt =
  try:
    let pos = instantiationInfo()
    discard(code)
    echo "Test failure at $1:$2 with '$3'" % [pos.filename,
      $pos.line, astToStr(code)]
    assert false, "A test expecting failure succeeded?"
  except exception:
    discard

proc tester(pos: int): int =
  let
    a = @[1, 2, 3]
  result = a[pos]

when isMainModule:
  testException(EInvalidIndex, tester(30))
  testException(EInvalidIndex, tester(1))
  # --> Test failure at example.nim:20 with 'tester(1)'
code:
proc instantiationInfo*(index = - 1; fullPaths = false): tuple[filename: string, 
    line: int] {.magic: "InstantiationInfo", noSideEffect.}

name: currentSourcePath
description: returns the full file-system path of the current source

name: assert
description: Raises AssertionError with msg if cond is false. Note that AssertionError is hidden from the effect system, so it doesn't produce {.raises: [AssertionError].}. This exception is only supposed to be caught by unit testing frameworks. The compiler may not generate any code at all for assert if it is advised to do so through the -d:release or --assertions:off command line switches.

name: doAssert
description: same as assert but is always turned on and not affected by the --assertions command line switch.

name: items
description: iterates over each item of <cite>a</cite>.

name: items
description: iterates over each item of <cite>a</cite>.

name: onFailedAssert
description:
Sets an assertion failure handler that will intercept any assert statements following onFailedAssert in the current lexical scope. Can be defined multiple times in a single function.
proc example(x: int): TErrorCode =
  onFailedAssert(msg):
    log msg
    return E_FAIL
  
  assert(...)
  
  onFailedAssert(msg):
    raise newException(EMyException, msg)
  
  assert(...)
code: template onFailedAssert*(msg: expr; code: stmt): stmt {.dirty, immediate.}

name: shallow
description: marks a sequence s as shallow. Subsequent assignments will not perform deep copies of s. This is only useful for optimization purposes.

name: shallow
description: marks a string s as shallow. Subsequent assignments will not perform deep copies of s. This is only useful for optimization purposes.

name: PNimrodNode
description: represents a Nim AST node. Macros operate on this type.

name: insert
description: inserts <cite>item</cite> into <cite>x</cite> at position <cite>i</cite>.
code: proc insert*(x: var string; item: string; i = 0) {.noSideEffect.}

name: compiles
description:
Special compile-time procedure that checks whether x can be compiled without any semantic error. This can be used to check whether a type supports some operation:
when not compiles(3 + 4):
  echo "'+' for integers is available"

name: safeAdd
code: proc safeAdd*[T](x: var seq[T]; y: T) {.noSideEffect.}

name: safeAdd
code: proc safeAdd*(x: var string; y: char)

name: safeAdd
code: proc safeAdd*(x: var string; y: string)

name: locals
description:
generates a tuple constructor expression listing all the local variables in the current scope. This is quite fast as it does not rely on any debug or runtime information. Note that in constrast to what the official signature says, the return type is not RootObj but a tuple of a structure that depends on the current scope. Example:
proc testLocals() =
  var
    a = "something"
    b = 4
    c = locals()
    d = "super!"
  
  b = 1
  for name, value in fieldPairs(c):
    echo "name ", name, " with value ", value
  echo "B is ", b
# -> name a with value something
# -> name b with value 4
# -> B is 1

name: deepCopy
description: performs a deep copy of x. This is also used by the code generator for the implementation of spawn.
code: proc deepCopy*[T](x: var T; y: T) {.noSideEffect, magic: "DeepCopy".}

name: procCall
description:
special magic to prohibit dynamic binding for method calls. This is similar to super in ordinary OO languages.
# 'someMethod' will be resolved fully statically:
procCall someMethod(a, b)
